pli-tv-kd4:0.3: The chapter on the invitation procedure
pli-tv-kd4:1.1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.
pli-tv-kd4:1.1.2: At that time in a certain monastery in the Kosalan country a number of monks who were friends had entered rainy-season residence together.
pli-tv-kd4:1.1.4: “How can we remain united and in harmony, have a comfortable rains residence, and get almsfood without trouble?”
pli-tv-kd4:1.2.3: Whoever returns first from almsround in the village should prepare the seats and set out a foot-stool, a foot-scraper, and water for washing the feet. He should clean the bowl for leftovers and set it out, and put out water for drinking and water for washing.
pli-tv-kd4:1.3.1: Whoever returns last from almsround may eat whatever is leftover, or he should discard it where there are no cultivated plants or in water without life.
pli-tv-kd4:1.3.2: He should put away the seats and also the foot-stool, the foot-scraper, and the water for washing the feet. He should clean the bowl for leftovers and put it away, put away the water for drinking and the water for washing, and sweep the dining hall.
pli-tv-kd4:1.4.1: Whoever sees that the pot for drinking water, the pot for washing water, or the waterpot in the restroom is empty should fill it.
pli-tv-kd4:1.4.2: If he can’t do it by himself, he should call someone over by hand signal and they should fill it together.
pli-tv-kd4:1.4.3: He should not speak because of that.
pli-tv-kd4:1.4.4: In this way we’ll remain united and in harmony, have a comfortable rains residence, and get almsfood without trouble.”
pli-tv-kd4:1.8.1: Now it was the custom for monks who had completed the rainy-season residence to go and visit the Buddha.
pli-tv-kd4:1.8.2: So when they had completed the rains residence and the three months had elapsed, those monks put their dwellings in order, took their bowls and robes, and left for Sāvatthī.
pli-tv-kd4:1.8.3: When they eventually arrived at Sāvatthī, they went to the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery. There they approached the Buddha, bowed, and sat down.
pli-tv-kd4:1.8.4: Since it is the custom for Buddhas to greet newly arrived monks,
pli-tv-kd4:1.9.2: “I hope you’re keeping well, monks, I hope you’re comfortable;
pli-tv-kd4:1.9.3: I hope you have had a comfortable rains residence, in concord and harmony, without dispute, and that you had no trouble getting almsfood.”
pli-tv-kd4:1.9.4: “We’re keeping well, Venerable Sir, we’re comfortable;
pli-tv-kd4:1.9.5: we’ve had a comfortable rains residence, in concord and harmony, without dispute, and we had no trouble getting almsfood.”
pli-tv-kd4:1.10.1: When Buddhas know what is going on, sometimes they ask and sometimes not;
pli-tv-kd4:1.10.2: they know the right time to ask and the right time not to ask.
pli-tv-kd4:1.10.3: Buddhas ask when it is beneficial, not when it is unbeneficial,
pli-tv-kd4:1.10.4: for Buddhas are incapable of doing what is unbeneficial.
pli-tv-kd4:1.10.5: Buddhas question the monks for two reasons: to give a teaching or to lay down a training rule.
pli-tv-kd4:1.10.6: And the Buddha said to those monks, “In what way, monks, did you have a comfortable rains residence, without having any trouble getting almsfood?”
pli-tv-kd4:1.12.1: When they had told him, the Buddha addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd4:1.12.2: “While they dwelt in discomfort these foolish men claim they were dwelling in comfort.
pli-tv-kd4:1.12.3: While they dwelt together like animals, they claim they were dwelling in comfort.
pli-tv-kd4:1.12.4: While they dwelt together like sheep, they claim they were dwelling in comfort.
pli-tv-kd4:1.12.5: While they dwelt together like enemies, they claim they were dwelling in comfort.
pli-tv-kd4:1.12.6: How can these foolish men take a vow of silence, as do the ascetics of other religions?
pli-tv-kd4:1.13.1: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it …” …
pli-tv-kd4:1.13.2: after criticizing them and giving a teaching, he addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd4:1.13.3: “You should not take a vow of silence, as do the ascetics of other religions.
pli-tv-kd4:1.13.4: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd4:1.13.5: When you have completed the rainy-season residence, you should invite the monks to correct you in regard to three things:
pli-tv-kd4:1.13.6: what has been seen, what has been heard, or what is suspected.
pli-tv-kd4:1.13.7: This will help you live with one another in the proper way, help you clear yourself of offenses, and help you give priority to the training.
pli-tv-kd4:1.14.1: And you should do the invitation procedure like this.
pli-tv-kd4:1.14.2: A competent and capable monk should inform the Sangha:
pli-tv-kd4:1.14.3: ʻPlease, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd4:1.14.5: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, it should do the invitation procedure.’
pli-tv-kd4:1.14.6: The most senior monk should put his upper robe over one shoulder, squat on his heels, raise his joined palms, and say:
pli-tv-kd4:1.14.7: ʻI invite the Sangha to correct me concerning what you have seen, what you have heard, and what you suspect.
pli-tv-kd4:1.14.8: Please correct me, Venerables, out of compassion.
pli-tv-kd4:1.14.9: If I see a fault, I will make amends.
pli-tv-kd4:1.14.10: For the second time, I invite the Sangha to correct me concerning what you have seen, what you have heard, and what you suspect.
pli-tv-kd4:1.14.11: Please correct me, Venerables, out of compassion.
pli-tv-kd4:1.14.12: If I see a fault, I will make amends.
pli-tv-kd4:1.14.13: For the third time, I invite the Sangha to correct me concerning what you have seen, what you have heard, and what you suspect.
pli-tv-kd4:1.14.14: Please correct me, Venerables, out of compassion.
pli-tv-kd4:1.14.15: If I see a fault, I will make amends.’
pli-tv-kd4:1.14.16: A junior monk should put his upper robe over one shoulder, squat on his heels, raise his joined palms, and say:
pli-tv-kd4:1.14.17: ʻI invite the Sangha to correct me concerning what you have seen, what you have heard, and what you suspect.

pli-tv-kd4:1.14.23: If I see a fault, I will make amends.’”
pli-tv-kd4:2.1.1: Soon afterwards the monks from the group of six remained seated while the senior monks were inviting correction, squatting on their heels.
pli-tv-kd4:2.1.2: The monks of few desires complained and criticized them,
pli-tv-kd4:2.1.3: “How can the monks from the group of six act like this?”
pli-tv-kd4:2.1.4: They told the Buddha. He had the Sangha gathered and questioned the monks:
pli-tv-kd4:2.1.5: “Is it true, monks, that the monks from the group of six were acting like this?”
pli-tv-kd4:2.1.8: “… How can those foolish men remain seated while the senior monks are inviting correction, squatting on their heels?”
pli-tv-kd4:2.1.9: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it or increase the confidence of those who have it …” …
pli-tv-kd4:2.1.11: he gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd4:2.1.12: “You should not remain seated while the senior monks are inviting correction, squatting on their heels.
pli-tv-kd4:2.1.13: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd4:2.1.14: Everyone should squat on their heels during the invitation procedure.”
pli-tv-kd4:2.2.1: On one occasion, while squatting on his heels and waiting for everyone to invite correction, a senior monk who was weak from old age fainted and fell over.
pli-tv-kd4:2.2.2: They told the Buddha and he said,
pli-tv-kd4:2.2.3: “You should squat on your heels until you have invited correction. Once you have invited, you may sit down.”
pli-tv-kd4:3.2.5: The invitation procedure that is illegitimate and has an incomplete assembly;
pli-tv-kd4:3.2.6: The invitation procedure that is illegitimate but has a complete assembly;
pli-tv-kd4:3.2.7: The invitation procedure that is legitimate but has an incomplete assembly;
pli-tv-kd4:3.2.8: The invitation procedure that is legitimate and has a complete assembly.
pli-tv-kd4:3.2.13: and third of these should not be done;
pli-tv-kd4:3.2.16: I have allowed such a procedure.
pli-tv-kd4:3.2.17: Therefore, monks, you should train like this: ʻWe will do invitation procedures that are legitimate and have a complete assembly.’”

pli-tv-kd4:3.3.4: A monk said to the Buddha,
pli-tv-kd4:3.3.5: “Sir, there’s a sick monk. He hasn’t come.”
pli-tv-kd4:3.3.6: “I allow a sick monk to pass on his invitation.
pli-tv-kd4:3.3.7: And it should be passed on like this.
pli-tv-kd4:3.3.8: The sick monk should approach a monk, put his upper robe over one shoulder, and squat on his heels. He should then raise his joined palms and say,
pli-tv-kd4:3.3.9: ʻI pass on my invitation; please convey my invitation; please announce my invitation; please invite correction on my behalf.’ If he makes this understood by body, by speech, or by body and speech, then the invitation has been passed on.
pli-tv-kd4:3.3.10: If he doesn’t make this understood by body, by speech, or by body and speech, then the invitation hasn’t been passed on.
pli-tv-kd4:3.4.1: If he’s able to do this, it’s good.
pli-tv-kd4:3.4.2: If not, then the sick monk should be brought into the midst of the Sangha together with his bed or bench. They can then do the invitation procedure.
pli-tv-kd4:3.4.3: But if the one who is nursing the sick monk says,
pli-tv-kd4:3.4.4: ʻIf we move him, his illness will get worse, or he’ll die,’ then the sick monk shouldn’t be moved.
pli-tv-kd4:3.4.5: The Sangha should go to where the sick monk is and do the invitation procedure there.
pli-tv-kd4:3.4.6: But you should not do the invitation procedure with an incomplete Sangha.
pli-tv-kd4:3.4.7: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-kd4:5.7.1: At one time on the invitation day a monk was staying in a certain monastery by himself.
pli-tv-kd4:5.7.3: “The Buddha has instructed that the invitation procedure should be done in the Sangha when there are five monks and with one another when there are two, three, or four.
pli-tv-kd4:5.7.5: How should I do the invitation procedure?”
pli-tv-kd4:5.8.1: “On the invitation day it may happen that a monk is staying by himself in a certain monastery.
pli-tv-kd4:5.8.2: That monk should sweep whatever place the monks normally go to: whether the assembly hall, under a roof-cover, or at the foot of a tree. He should set out water for drinking and water for washing, should prepare a seat, light a lamp, and sit down.
pli-tv-kd4:5.8.3: If other monks come, he should do the invitation procedure with them.
pli-tv-kd4:5.8.4: If not, he should determine: ʻToday is my invitation procedure.’
pli-tv-kd4:5.8.5: If he doesn’t make a determination, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd4:5.9.1: Wherever five monks are staying together, four shouldn’t do the invitation procedure in the Sangha while bringing the invitation of one.
pli-tv-kd4:5.9.2: If you do it in this way, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd4:5.9.3: Wherever four monks are staying together, three shouldn’t do the invitation procedure with one another while bringing the invitation of one.
pli-tv-kd4:5.9.4: If you do it in this way, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-kd4:5.9.6: If you do it in this way, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd4:5.9.7: Wherever two monks are staying together, one shouldn’t make a determination while bringing the invitation of one.
pli-tv-kd4:5.9.8: If you make a determination in this way, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd4:6.1.0: The process for making amends for an offense
pli-tv-kd4:6.1.1: At one time on the invitation day a certain monk had committed an offense.
pli-tv-kd4:6.1.3: “The Buddha has laid down a rule
pli-tv-kd4:6.1.4: that one shouldn’t invite correction if one has an offense.
pli-tv-kd4:6.1.7: They told the Buddha and he said,
pli-tv-kd4:6.1.8: “On the invitation day it may happen that a monk has committed an offense.
pli-tv-kd4:6.1.9: He should approach a single monk, put his upper robe over one shoulder, squat on his heels, raise his joined palms, and say,
pli-tv-kd4:6.1.10: ʻI have committed such-and-such an offense. I confess it.’
pli-tv-kd4:6.1.14: ‘You should restrain yourself in the future.’
pli-tv-kd4:6.1.15: On the invitation day it may happen that a monk is unsure if he’s committed an offense.
pli-tv-kd4:6.1.16: He should approach a single monk, put his upper robe over one shoulder, squat on his heels, raise his joined palms, and say,
pli-tv-kd4:6.1.17: ʻI’m unsure if I’ve committed such-and-such an offense.
pli-tv-kd4:6.1.18: I will make amends for it when I’m sure.’ They can then do the invitation procedure.
pli-tv-kd4:6.1.19: You shouldn’t allow this to create an obstacle to the doing of the invitation procedure.”
pli-tv-kd4:6.2.0: The process for revealing an offense

pli-tv-kd4:6.2.3: “The Buddha has laid down a rule
pli-tv-kd4:6.2.4: that one shouldn’t invite correction if one has an offense.
pli-tv-kd4:6.2.7: They told the Buddha and he said,
pli-tv-kd4:6.2.8: “It may happen that a monk remembers an offense during the invitation procedure.
pli-tv-kd4:6.2.9: He should say to a monk sitting next to him,

pli-tv-kd4:6.2.12: You shouldn’t allow this to create an obstacle to the doing of the invitation procedure.
pli-tv-kd4:6.3.1: It may happen during the invitation procedure that a monk becomes unsure if he’s committed an offense.
pli-tv-kd4:6.3.2: He should say to a monk sitting next to him,

pli-tv-kd4:6.3.5: You shouldn’t allow this to create an obstacle to the doing of the invitation procedure.”
pli-tv-kd4:6.3.6.0: The process for making amends for a shared offense
pli-tv-kd4:6.3.6.1: At one time on the invitation day the whole sangha in a certain monastery had committed the same offense.
pli-tv-kd4:6.3.8: “The Buddha has laid down a rule
pli-tv-kd4:6.3.9: that one shouldn’t confess or receive the confession of shared offenses.
pli-tv-kd4:6.3.10: But here the whole sangha has committed the same offense.
pli-tv-kd4:6.3.13: “On the invitation day it may happen that the whole sangha in a certain monastery has committed the same offense.
pli-tv-kd4:6.3.14: Those monks should straightaway send one monk to a neighboring monastery:
pli-tv-kd4:6.3.15: ʻGo and make amends for this offense. When you return, we’ll make amends for it in your presence.’
pli-tv-kd4:6.3.16: If he’s able to do so, it’s good.
pli-tv-kd4:6.3.17: If not, then a competent and capable monk should inform the Sangha:
pli-tv-kd4:6.3.18: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd4:6.3.19: This whole sangha has committed the same offense.
pli-tv-kd4:6.3.20: When the Sangha sees another monk who is pure and free from offenses, it should make amends for this offense in his presence.’

pli-tv-kd4:6.3.22: You shouldn’t allow this to create an obstacle to the doing of the invitation procedure.
pli-tv-kd4:6.3.23: “On the invitation day it may happen that the whole sangha in a certain monastery is unsure if it has committed the same offense.
pli-tv-kd4:6.3.24: A competent and capable monk should then inform the Sangha:

pli-tv-kd4:6.3.27: When the Sangha is sure, it should make amends for this offense.’
pli-tv-kd4:6.3.28: Once this has been said, they can do the invitation procedure. You shouldn’t allow this to create an obstacle to the doing of the invitation procedure.”

pli-tv-kd4:16.19.0: Grounds for a serious offense, etc.
pli-tv-kd4:16.19.1: “It may happen on the invitation day that a monk has committed a serious offense.
pli-tv-kd4:16.19.2: Some monks regard it as a serious offense, but others as an offense entailing suspension.
pli-tv-kd4:16.19.3: The monks who regard it as a serious offense should take that monk to one side and deal with him according to the rule. They should then approach the Sangha and say:
pli-tv-kd4:16.19.4: ‘This monk has made amends for the offense he’s committed.
pli-tv-kd4:16.19.5: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, the Sangha should do the invitation procedure.’

pli-tv-kd4:16.23.0: Setting aside of an offense, etc.
pli-tv-kd4:16.23.1: “It may happen on the invitation day that a monk says in the middle of the Sangha:
pli-tv-kd4:16.23.2: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd4:16.23.3: I know about an offense, but not who the offender is.
pli-tv-kd4:16.23.4: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, it should set aside the offense and then do the invitation procedure.’
pli-tv-kd4:16.23.6: ‘The Buddha has laid down a rule that the invitation procedure is for monks who are pure.
pli-tv-kd4:16.23.7: If you know the offense, but not the offender, then say now who it is that you suspect.’
pli-tv-kd4:16.24.1: “It may happen on the invitation day that a monk says in the middle of the Sangha:

pli-tv-kd4:16.26.1: “If the offense is known about before the invitation procedure, but the offender only afterwards, the offender should be corrected.
pli-tv-kd4:16.26.2: If the offender is known about before the invitation procedure, but the offense only afterwards, the offender should be corrected.
pli-tv-kd4:16.26.3: If both the offense and the offender are known about before the invitation procedure, and someone reopens the case after the invitation procedure has been done, he commits an offense entailing confession for the reopening.”
pli-tv-kd4:17.1.1: On one occasion in a certain monastery in the Kosalan country, a number of monks who were friends had entered the rainy-season residence together.
pli-tv-kd4:17.1.2: Other monks who were quarrelsome, argumentative, and creators of legal issues in the Sangha had entered the rains residence nearby. These monks said to one another,
pli-tv-kd4:17.1.3: “At the invitation procedure, when those monks have completed the rains residence, we’ll cancel their invitation.”
pli-tv-kd4:17.1.4: The monks who were friends heard about this
pli-tv-kd4:17.1.8: They told the Buddha and he said,
pli-tv-kd4:17.2.4: I allow those monks to do two or three observance-day ceremonies on the fourteenth
pli-tv-kd4:17.2.5: with the aim of having their invitation procedure before the other monks.
pli-tv-kd4:17.2.6: “If those quarrelsome and argumentative monks are on their way to the other monastery, the resident monks should gather quickly and do the invitation procedure. When it has been done, they should say to the other monks,
pli-tv-kd4:17.2.7: ‘Venerables, we have completed the invitation procedure;
pli-tv-kd4:17.2.8: please do whatever you think is appropriate.’
pli-tv-kd4:17.3.1: If those quarrelsome and argumentative monks arrive without prior notice, the resident monks should prepare seats and set out a foot-stool, a foot-scraper, and water for washing the feet. They should then go out to meet those monks, receive their bowl and robe, and ask if they want water to drink.
pli-tv-kd4:17.3.2: Then, having distracted them, they should go outside the monastic boundary and do the invitation procedure there. When it has been done, they should say to the other monks,
pli-tv-kd4:17.3.3: ‘Venerables, we have completed the invitation procedure;
pli-tv-kd4:17.3.4: please do whatever you think is appropriate.’
pli-tv-kd4:17.4.1: “If they’re able to do this, it’s good.
pli-tv-kd4:17.4.2: If not, then a resident monk who is competent and capable should inform the resident monks:
pli-tv-kd4:17.4.3: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the resident monks to listen.
pli-tv-kd4:17.4.4: If it seems appropriate to the venerables, we will now do the observance-day procedure by reciting the Monastic Code, and we will do the invitation procedure at the next new moon.’
pli-tv-kd4:17.4.5: If the quarrelsome and argumentative monks say,
pli-tv-kd4:17.4.6: ‘It would be good if you would do the invitation procedure with us now,’ they should be told,
pli-tv-kd4:17.4.7: ‘You have no authority over our invitation procedure.
pli-tv-kd4:17.4.8: We won’t do the procedure for the time being.’
pli-tv-kd4:17.5.1: If the quarrelsome and argumentative monks stay on until the new moon, then a resident monk who is competent and capable should inform the resident monks:
pli-tv-kd4:17.5.2: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the resident monks to listen.
pli-tv-kd4:17.5.3: If it seems appropriate to the venerables, we will now do the observance-day procedure by reciting the Monastic Code, and we will do the invitation procedure at the next full moon.’
pli-tv-kd4:17.5.4: If the quarrelsome and argumentative monks say,
pli-tv-kd4:17.5.5: ‘It would be good if you would do the invitation procedure with us now,’ they should be told,
pli-tv-kd4:17.5.6: ‘You have no authority over our invitation procedure. We won’t do the procedure for the time being.’
pli-tv-kd4:17.6.1: If the quarrelsome and argumentative monks stay on even until the next full moon, then all the monks have no choice but to do the invitation procedure on the day of Komudī, the fourth full moon of the rainy season.
pli-tv-kd4:17.7.1: “If, while you’re doing the invitation procedure, a sick monk cancels the invitation of a healthy monk, you should tell him,
pli-tv-kd4:17.7.3: The Buddha has said that a sick monk can’t endure being questioned.
pli-tv-kd4:17.7.5: If you then wish, you may accuse him.’
pli-tv-kd4:17.7.6: If, in spite of this, he still accuses the other, he commits an offense entailing confession for disrespect.
pli-tv-kd4:17.8.1: If, while you’re doing the invitation procedure, a healthy monk cancels the invitation of a sick monk, you should tell him,
pli-tv-kd4:17.8.3: The Buddha has said that a sick monk can’t endure being questioned.
pli-tv-kd4:17.8.5: If you then wish, you may accuse him.’
pli-tv-kd4:17.8.6: If, in spite of this, he still accuses the other, he commits an offense entailing confession for disrespect.
pli-tv-kd4:17.9.1: If, while you’re doing the invitation procedure, a sick monk cancels the invitation of a sick monk, you should tell him,
pli-tv-kd4:17.9.3: The Buddha has said that a sick monk can’t endure being questioned.
pli-tv-kd4:17.9.4: Please wait until you’re both healthy.
pli-tv-kd4:17.9.5: If you then wish, you may accuse him.’
pli-tv-kd4:17.9.6: If, in spite of this, he still accuses the other, he commits an offense entailing confession for disrespect.
pli-tv-kd4:17.10.1: If, while you’re doing the invitation procedure, a healthy monk cancels the invitation of a healthy monk, you should question and examine both and deal with them according to the rule. The Sangha should then continue the invitation procedure.”
pli-tv-kd4:18.1.1: On one occasion in a certain monastery in the Kosalan country, a number of monks who were friends had entered the rainy-season residence together.
pli-tv-kd4:18.1.2: While they were dwelling in unity and harmony, they attained a certain pleasant state of meditation.
pli-tv-kd4:18.1.5: and thought, “If we do the invitation procedure now, the monks might leave to go wandering.
pli-tv-kd4:18.1.6: We will then have lost this pleasant abiding.
pli-tv-kd4:18.1.8: They told the Buddha and he said,
pli-tv-kd4:18.2.7: I allow those monks to make an agreement about the invitation procedure.
pli-tv-kd4:18.3.1: And it should be made like this.
pli-tv-kd4:18.3.2: Everyone should gather in one place.
pli-tv-kd4:18.3.3: A competent and capable monk should then inform the Sangha:
pli-tv-kd4:18.3.4: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd4:18.3.5: While dwelling in unity and harmony, we have attained a certain pleasant state of meditation.
pli-tv-kd4:18.3.6: If we do the invitation procedure now, the monks might leave to go wandering.
pli-tv-kd4:18.3.7: We will then have lost this pleasant abiding.
pli-tv-kd4:18.3.8: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, the Sangha should make an agreement about the invitation procedure: we will now do the observance-day procedure by reciting the Monastic Code, and we will do the invitation procedure on the day of Komudī, the fourth full moon of the rainy season.
pli-tv-kd4:18.4.1: Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd4:18.4.2: While dwelling in unity and harmony, we have attained a certain pleasant state of meditation.
pli-tv-kd4:18.4.3: If we do the invitation procedure now, the monks might leave to go wandering.
pli-tv-kd4:18.4.4: We will then have lost this pleasant abiding.
pli-tv-kd4:18.4.5: The Sangha makes an agreement about the invitation procedure: we will now do the observance-day procedure by reciting the Monastic Code, and we will do the invitation procedure on the day of Komudī, the fourth full moon of the rainy season.
pli-tv-kd4:18.4.6: Any monk who approves of making this agreement about the invitation procedure—that we will now do the observance-day procedure by reciting the Monastic Code and that we will do the invitation procedure on the day of Komudī, the fourth full moon of the rainy season—should remain silent.
pli-tv-kd4:18.4.7: Any monk who does not approve should speak up.
pli-tv-kd4:18.4.8: The Sangha has made an agreement about the invitation procedure: we will now do the observance-day procedure by reciting the Monastic Code, and we will do the invitation procedure on the day of Komudī, the fourth full moon of the rainy season.
pli-tv-kd4:18.4.9: The Sangha approves and is therefore silent. I will remember it thus.’
pli-tv-kd4:18.5.1: “If, when those monks have made an agreement about the invitation procedure, a monk says,
pli-tv-kd4:18.5.2: ‘I wish to go wandering in the country;
pli-tv-kd4:18.5.3: I have something to do there,’ they should tell him,
pli-tv-kd4:18.5.4: ‘That’s fine, but you have to do the invitation first.’
pli-tv-kd4:18.5.5: If, while that monk is doing the invitation, he cancels the invitation of another monk, the other monk should tell him,
pli-tv-kd4:18.5.6: ‘You have no authority over my invitation until I invite.’
pli-tv-kd4:18.5.7: If, while that monk is doing the invitation, another monk cancels his invitation, the monks should question and examine both and deal with them according to the rule.
pli-tv-kd4:18.6.1: “It may be that that monk finishes his business in the country and returns to that monastery before the full-moon day of Komudī. If, while the monks are doing the invitation procedure, a monk cancels the invitation of the monk who has returned, the monk who has returned should tell him,
pli-tv-kd4:18.6.2: ‘You have no authority over my invitation;
pli-tv-kd4:18.6.4: If, while the monks are doing the invitation procedure, the monk who has returned cancels the invitation of another monk, the monks should question and examine both and deal with them according to the rule. The Sangha should then continue the invitation procedure.”
